This was truly a boring film with an irritating kid i wanted less and less to see in the story .It was poorly directed with a plot line that seemed to go nowhere and stayed on the same plane for the entire film.

I just saw this movie. The first thing I had to get over was that I instantly recognized Christian Bale as the lead child. Ordinarily I wouldn't have to "get over" that, but since I have seen him in the magnificent American Pysco, it was hard to forget that he played that and he was just an innocent child.Once I got over that, I felt the movie was relatively good. It didn't have the brutality the Japanese most assuredly had for the English while they were in the camp. In fact, there was almost an aversion to showing any brutality from the oppressor. It was a little disappointing.However, it was incredibly interesting to see how my in-laws could have had it if they hadn't gotten out of there when they did. I did have an emotionally moment when he sees his parents - it was awful. I couldn't imagine. The parents were kind of stale, but Bale rose to the occasion. He has a strong future!

I did not fully understand when I first saw Empire of the Sun. I was unsettled by the mixed-up story about the survival of a war orphan who idolized both an American profiteer (John Malkovich) and the Japanese fighter pilots.Then the revelation during my second viewing:  Empire of the Sun is entirely from THE PERSPECTIVE OF A CHILD!  Everything fell into place.  It's the experience and understanding of a young boy, surviving amidst an enormous drama, seeking role models to guide him to adulthood.  It's a marvelous film.

Spielberg I feel put it all out in this film. Who he is, and what he's not willing to compromise. The story, the beauty and horror in great scope through the eyes of a young lad. I get goosebumps and tears every time. So worth watching this sometimes forgotten part of ww2.

For some reason about a month ago, I felt like renting Empire Of the Sun again after not seeing much of it in about 9 or 10 years. The first time I saw it, I was living in Hong Kong so the China angle didn't mean much to me. And perhaps I was too young (18/19) or impatient to fully grasp the depth of the performances and story. Well, this past couple times it was a different matter entirely. I found the film to be outstanding, even beautiful at times.Christian Bale gave perhaps one of the most incredible performances I've seen for any actor, not just one of his age in the film. You'll be amazed. And the scenes of Shanghai were awesome. From my own experience in Hong Kong, I had no trouble believing that was really Shanghai.Anyone reading this who has not seen the film yet, see it. Take what everyone else here has said as more than just hype. You'll be glad you took the time to watch the film through. It's a gift I think. A gift, given to 'the master of directing', cause that's what he is for me. This movie is just as moving as E.T. I really cried at the end when he finally found his parents. So I just want to give my thanks to Steven and of course to Jim. Thanks.  Esther

reviews.review_title: One of the truly great films
reviews.content: This is the best movie Spielberg ever made.  The sound track itself is a masterpiece with some of the most beautiful music you will ever hear. When I saw this film in 1987 I immediately ran out to purchase it.  The visual effects are  surrealistic and gorgeous.I had never heard of John Malkovich until this movie but since than I have followed every thing he has done. It is impossible to over praise the performance of Christian Bale. He will bring tears to your eyes as the movie ends. Don't just rent this film but buy one as you will want to see it again and again.

Outstanding film in all senses. Not only it shows you the complexity of war itself, but also the beauty behind the lives of the unfortunate people who have to suffer it.A must see for the Christian Bale lovers out there, as he does an amazing role with a high level of commitment(and you can see glimpses of the great actor he is going to become. Malkovich is also excellent here.Now, the real beauty of this film is that it shows war as it is; there is no real "good" side fighting it. Both Americans and Japanese did horrible things, something that other war movies seem to dismiss. The soundtrack is absolutely outstanding. A 10/10.

reviews.review_title: Closely resembles a work of art
reviews.content: Bale is excellent(fantastic, amazing, brilliant, shockingly good) in the lead role with strong performances no matter how trivial they are from the rest of the supporting cast. Spielberg works to provide an amazing story here presented in strong emotive colors. The end result is excellence and although the director, yet again, dabbles a bit too far in sentimentality - he can be forgiven as what is produced is a rounded scope on humanity and how that can come through in such hard times. Scenes that resemble paintings of great art include the crowd sequence at the beginning along with the bombing scene and of course the salute. There is also an hilarious cameo from Ben Stiller although I don't think it was meant to be. A great film that is slightly underrated in history and closely resembles a work of art. Go see it.

Two of the most powerful performances of my generation were presented in this cinematic masterpiece. Christian Bale's initial blockbuster role could arguably be his best ever. Playing an eight year old boy who becomes lost during the panic of the Japanese attack on Shang Hai in the early years of World War II; through several years of survival in various internment camps until the end of the war. Bale's portrayal of a somewhat ADD afflicted youth was pinnacle to the success of the film. He was astonishing, and anchored the production very well. John Malkovich played the antagonist to the hyperactive child brilliantly and added another very round character to the film. Although the film centers mainly on Jim and Basie, there are some subplots that were included, but could have been developed better. Dr. Rawlins struggle to save his patients and his obvious resistance to his Japanese guardians was not well developed although it was a key event more to develop Jim's character than to present or fulfill the Dr. Rawlins character.The cinematography of Empire of the Sun was stunning. The party scene of Jim playing with his glider and finding the downed Zero. Then subsequently "discovering" the Japanese soldiers was very well done. The Shang Hai city scenario was stunning in it's panorama and detail. The fade in to Jim obviously older and wiser in the internment camp, with him running around still the hyperactive child at the beginning, meeting everyone exchanging and bartering. The dogfight scenes with the P-51 Mustangs, and Jim yelling, "the Cadillac of the skies!!" and him running back and forth on the roof; to the final scenes of the prisoners march north, and Jim seeing Mrs. Victor's soul flying into heaven (the bomb being dropped on Nagasaki). These all contributed to an absolutely riveting film experience.The only part of the film that I can truly say is overdone is when the Japanes pilot gets shot, and Jim tries to resuscitate him. I really was ready for him to stop yelling after the fifth or sixth repetition of his line. The film was neither anticlimactic nor was it an overly happy ending. Jim finally is reunited with his parents, yet the scars of surviving basically on his own are forever impressed in his eyes. A scene that I will always remember.

I haven't prepared anything, but had to throw in a word for Christian Bale. Granted, as with any Spielberg film, the ultimate star of the film is Spielberg.  (And all films should have that kind of star!)  But Christian Bale's performance is a bloody miracle.  He is in virtually every shot of the film, and he is consistently fascinating.  I pull out "Empire" when I need a good cry.  If I'm in a hurry, I fast-forward to, first, the camp liberation scene ("B-52!! Cadillac of the skies!!!") -- that gets me started -- and then to the final scene.  The shot of him slowly recognizing his parents is astonishing.  Why this performance has gone relatively unlauded is beyond me.  I defy actors three or four times his age to carry a film with the deftness and artistry Christian Bale does "Empire of the Sun".

I saw Empire of the Sun on it's opening night on one of Michigan's largest screens at that time.  This was one of the most Awesome movie experiences I have ever had.  Spielberg and John Williams are the BEST!  I am very surprised this film did not win best picture.  If anyone has not seen this film, see it on a Good home theater system.

I first saw "Empire of the Sun" in 10th grade as part of our curriculum for World War II.  That was the first film I cried as I watched it. Spielberg's awe inspiring style which continues throughout each of his films is clearly seen here.  From the clean, British home which young Jim grows up in, to the Soo Chow Internment Camp where he comes of age shows the  surreal nature of many scenes in this film.  A film which has many great parts has one stunning facet.  John Williams' great score which is amoung his best(Star Wars, Superman, Saving Private Ryan) shows the whole spectrum, from the Welsh hymns to the Asian inspired music was incredible.  The best scene in the movie features the Hiroshima atomic destruction.  What more can you say than Spielberg's genius.

I still rent and watch this movie for really only one scene. And even as I viewed the trailer to this movie moments ago on this website, it made my heart beat faster. The scene where the beautiful, lovely war machine known as the P-51 Mustang in her silver sleek skin flew by the building that had the 12-year old standing atop, yelling at the top of his lungs, "P-51, Cadillac of the Sky" repeatedly. In enters the roar, power, and beauty of the American air supremacy that we enjoyed back when the P-51 was in her day. The pilot had his canopy slung back, and his scarf trailing in the air still is impressed in my image. For this boy, the man piloting this beautiful plane was god-like. The scene captured all the emotion of that moment, and I tip my hat to Steven Spielberg for creating such a wonderful image that is probably my favorite scene in any movie overall. Why? The love affair we had with WWII planes and also the new planes that exist today. If you're an American patriot that is proud to wear your national pride and respect for our capability on your sleeve, watch the full movie to see this scene and it will double your heart rate, I guarantee it.

reviews.review_title: An emersive movie in every sense

reviews.review_title: A stunning movie, based upon a true story.
reviews.content: Anyone who has read at least a few of the reviews here, will at least know the basis of the story. But it amazes me how few people understand its origins, and how wonderfully it translated in to the movie medium.The story is based upon the life of J. G. Ballard (James... Jim), and the true story of how he became separated from his parents at the sacking of Shanghai, by the Japanese, which formally opened hostilities between Japan and China. Jim's father was essentially a 'tai-pan' of shanghai, the English political men with the money. As the invasion happened, with all of these wealthy people trying to escape, Jim was separated, and proceeded to live out the war off his own wits, and through the prison camps and eventual liberation by the Americans. J. G. Ballard wrote the book as an auto-biographical story of his life, and even with a little bit of (well done) creative license by Spielberg, the story (and more importantly, message) more or less remains the same.This was the second world war, remember? It lasted a long long time, and many many people died, a significant portion of which perished in the prison camps administered by the Japanese. There are a also a number of reviewers here that talk of the similarities to King Rat, as if it is some sort of 'rip-off'. King Rat and Tai-Pan were both written by James Clavell, one of the survivors of Changi, another prison camp administered by the Japanese. The similarities exist because both stories occurred in basically the same environment, as told by some of the people that lived through them.It is Steven Spielbergs best movie. And in his first movie, masterfully directed, and proof that he has always been a great actor, Christian Bale. With John Malkovich as imperious as ever, and so many other fine actors like Nigel Havers, Joe Pantoliano, and Miranda Richardson.It is a beautifully done movie, about a boy on his own, growing up in the most tragic, and yet awe-inspiring of circumstances. And if people can't see the truth in the acting, then it probably has more to do with not believing real-life, even when it's right in front of them.

reviews.review_title: The Brilliance of Empire of the Sun
reviews.content:
I saw this film a few weeks ago for a film studies project and I became completely captivated by the performance of young Christian Bale. As someone who has never experienced war but only seen depictions of it in movies, this film completely changed my view on World War Two. I admire how respectfully Spielberg depicts the Japanese soldiers in this film. Although there are scenes of great violence toward the camp members, the Japanese soldiers are portrayed as humans rather than the common villain like version often seen in movies. Jim's relationship with the Japanese pilot helped me empathize with both sides of the war. In reality the majority of soldiers in World War Two were victims to violence that they had little control over.
I recommend this movie for students who are looking for a different view on World War Two. Often Nazi Germany is the main focus of attention in the classroom setting. However, this film shows how far stretching the World War Two actually was and is effective in broadening one's mindset. Empire of the Sun will most likely make you question what it means to be loyal to your home country and ponder the far reaching effects of war.
I watched this movie over 10 times - young Christian Bale was incredible! The script is just enlightening- even though it's a much better concentration camp than my dad experienced in Vietnam.

They don't make movies this great anymore, or at least, I haven't seen any such lately. It is an epic, as I think it was meant to be, but the director achieved more, perhaps than he thought.  The credit belongs chiefly to the young actor, Christian Bale, whose career,I confess, I have not followed, but who, among a well selected cast, not the least of whom are John Malkovich and Miranda Richardson (anyone ever seen a BAD movie that John Malkovich was in?)are the pivotal players, and truly make the film.  An incredible support cast does a great effort, and succedes in a flawless line of action. [Did you notice Ben Stiller? He's in there for a small part, but, of course, done well. Remember the old line, "there are no small parts; only small actors"? This gives one a look at a "small part" for a future great actor. From the first time I saw this film, in the '80's, I have been haunted by the music [John Williams] and the performances, especially of the child actor.  I greatly disagree with a previous reviewer that this is in any way a David Lean wannabe film.  In fact, I believe it is truly unique, even for Spielberg, and all connected with the film.  I am a member of this era and everything from the mannerisms to the hairstyles are so very correct.  The only thing I ever noticed was that the silver dollar (used as a golf chip and later found by "Jamie" in the pool) seemed to be anachronistic, but I may be wrong.  I have watched many times, and perhaps my eyes are not as good as they once were. This most assuredly stays on my "100 Favorite" list, and heartily do I advise those who know not of this history to view it.  I am buying a copy for my grandchildren's library.  It is not only a good film, it is an important film, about which I can say that few make the list.  If you view and are interested by this film, I suggest that you read and view "The Good Earth", written by Pearl S. Buck.  Even now, with all the digital properties of movies, the special effects are remarkable, and the acting, characterization is superb.  It gives the viewers a background on China in pre-WWII times, from the view of the Chinese peasants. In any case, I suspect that "Empire of The Sun" will grow in it's ability to attract viewers, and in a most engaging manner.  It is difficult to view this film with emotional detachment, especially for one who remembers WWII, or for anyone who was once a child.

The movie is visually and emotionally stunning.Christian Bale is so perfect that it hurts to watch his growing isolation, his desperation to be connected.Personally, I think it's Spielberg's masterpiece.

reviews.review_title: Excellent film, most certainly a classic

This is a story many people have never heard of, we've all heard the stories of internment camps in the US for Japanese citizens, but who's heard of the Japanese camps that held Americans, Brits and other foreigners. If The Doors was Oliver Stone's baby, then Empire of the Sun is Spielberg's. This is his signature piece, if not his masterpiece: from the airplanes to the rolling dolly shots to the film stock quality, Empire of the Sun reflects all that is great about Spielberg's craftsmanship as a film maker without the  bombast and over-sentimentality.  The scale of the film is enormous, the production values incomparable. You can feel that no effort was spared to recreate the world recorded in J.G. Ballard's novel--from the crowds of Shanghai to the concentration camps, the Kafkaesque compound of confiscated goods in a vast open field in China, parachutes containing rations dropping from the sky: every scene is perfectly realized. Even Kubrick could not have done better. The atomic bomb blast sequence is hauntingly realistic and ominous.  Who can forget that scene when Jim tries to retrieve his glider and sees a line of Japanese aviators on a hill in the distance, taking up the entire movie frame? The lighting of the sky, the ominous mood--pure cinematic genius. This is also one of Spielberg's most subtle films in terms of characterization--Christian Bale is superb as is John Malkevich--both convey how individuals cope with the horrors of war with acceptance and pragmatism. I have to say that this film is superior to both Saving Private Ryan and Schindler's List as an organic work of art, as well an archetypal story for all nations. I am not a big fan of Spielberg, but Empire of the Sun gets my vote as his masterpiece.

This has to be the best film I've seen in quite a while. Two scenes give me shivers on my skin every time I watch them. The part where Jim sings and salutes in the sunset while the Kamakazi pilots are preparing to get into their zeros. And the scene where  Jim has a near face to face contact with the liberating American pilot - the slow motion of that scene is so poignant that my video on that part is almost rubbed off! What an amazing array of characters and situations thrown together by force. You are almost relieved that Jim is too young and innocent to face the terrible consequences of his predicament. His way of dealing with day to day life ensures his survival.

reviews.review_title: Brilliant story of a boy's growth through extreme circumstances

Everything from the use of light, which Speilberg is a master at, to the scenery within a Japanese prison camp is exquisite.Christian Bale (as a child) and John Malkovich are both brilliant and you can see why their careers have gone so far from this mid-80's film.In closing, this is one of about a dozen films that I have seen in my life that has made me cry.  It is about 2 and a half hours long but it is a true poem of a film and will make any viewer appreciate it for the work of art that it is.  It is one of the best films that I have ever seen.

With Empire of the Sun, Steven Spielberg transformed into cinema the dark vision of the world and its future of the novelist,  J. G. Ballard.  Of course credit should also be given to brilliant scriptwriter Tom Stoppard, but in this film, Spielberg presents a story of a traumatized British boy's shifting identity as "empires" shred, with power shifting from Britain in China to Japan, then to the nuclear terror "empire of the sun" of the newly-harnessed atomic weaponry of the United States.  But by all three of its `authors,' this story of ideological shifting is as much about the world at war as about the boy Jim's separation from and longing for his parents -- to whom does this lost boy belong?  Jim is struggling to know who he is, and how to function in a world where arbitrary and shifting power becomes the only absolute.  Jim needs a nurturing mother and a legitimately authoritative father.  The story of Empire is the story of Jim's struggling search, and our search with him, for a sense of belonging in a world where violent power has become absolute. The two words, "ideology" and "identity" share much common meaning. Because he is struggling to grow up -- coming of age -- at the same time as he is separated from his parents in war, Jim is struggling to find an identity.  Ordinarily, one knows what is "the same" with one's own values by means of a symbol-system, or ideology.  But Jim's values and emerging identity are bombarded by the collapse of such systems, and he must first struggle to survive, physically and spiritually.  Through the eyes and the mind and heart of Jim, the novel's author, J. G. Ballard, presents an autobiographical narrative of his own experiences in Shanghai and Japanese internment camps in China.  Ultimately, at the end of the film, it is questionable whether or not Jim has been able to integrate his experiences with suffering and death when we look into his empty, traumatized eyes. He is found by his parents, and is being embraced by his mother, but we do not know his future. In his young world of fantasy where might is right and beautiful, Jim dreams of airplanes -- symbols, fetishes and talismans, the ultimate incarnations of power.  For Jim they are dreamlike, exalted objects of worship.  Jim is a boy who is deeply enamored with the new technologies of war.  His every day- and night-time dream is filled with visions of the newest warplanes and their dogfights and bombing raids.  So, increasingly, he binds himself to the imagery of death technology in American media.  He grows to love their violence.   Jim's problem with his identity, with his sense of  to whom and to what set of values he belongs, is represented to us with this fascination of his with airplanes.  He tries to compensate his missing and lost family love with his love for planes and flying.  In one scene when Jim and the displaced Europeans are brought into a camp to help build an airport runway, Jim sees a Japanese Zero being worked on in a hanger.  He slowly approaches and lovingly caresses it while choral music builds, and a surreal background of soft lighting, light from welders' torches, smoke and golden sparks from grinders presents us with another seemingly supernatural scene. Three Japanese pilots approach the plane, and when Jim sees them, he slowly comes to reverent military attention, and he and the Japanese exchange salutes. Planes not only substitute for his parents.  In one scene, when American planes bomb and strafe the airfield, Jim shouts hysterically, "I touched them!  I felt their heat!  I could taste them in my mouth!  Oil and cordite!"  We know that Jim is deprived of parents, and we also know of the importance of food symbols and the motif of  starvation in the film.  But this is the first time that Jim's seeking, and finding, of nurturing from the airplane is made explicit.  His friend and, to some degree, father substitute, Dr. Ransome rushes up onto the roof where Jim is running and shouting crazily and tells him to "Get down!" and "Stop thinking so much!" Jim weeps, telling the doctor that he can't remember what his parents look like, then goes into a trance-like state, and chants his Latin lessons which he has been working on with Dr. Ransome, but with the words: "Amatus sum," I am loved. In the novel, Jim witnessed American planes shot down, and the pilots unable to eject, and burning alive in their seats.  As with the kamikaze pilots, these pilots are just part of the weaponry machinery.  They cannot separate.  The order of this war-time structure means that even Jim himself also has no individual human worth apart from the military machine.  Ideas of individual coherence or integrity have less and less meaning as the war, and Jim's experience of being lost within it, continue. "Despite everything, he knew he was worth nothing."  The deaths of the pilots were "a premonition of his death, the sight of his soul joining the larger soul of the dying world."  His cheerful American friends in the camp turn out in the end only to be other servants of death.  When he learns of the new weapon, the atomic bomb, Jim knows that they also are not only destroyers of human bodies, but also of distinct, autonomous selfhood. Basie tells Jim that since he has seen the bomb, he might appear in Life. Up until the point of the dropping of the bomb and his experience of Mrs. Victor's ascent, all Jim's actions lead in the direction of fulfilling his obligations to death in war.   Since only as an object of death can he be fully known and "loved", Jim is only perfected in his weakness and submission to the machinery of death.   At the end of the war, after the atomic weapon has been used, has the fighting really ended?  Jim becomes aware, with the killing of his kamikaze friend that he has entered a world where there could be no leaving behind the horror of war, where war has become total. In a scene reminiscent of the hospital attempted revival, an American has stupidly shot dead Jim's young kamikaze friend  just as the Japanese boy had given Jim a mango and they were about to share it, providing Jim with a little of the nurturing he so desperately needs and desires.  Jim is shocked and outraged by the stupid, wanton killing.  The night before this attempted magical revival scene, Jim had just witnessed the explosion of the atomic bomb, immediately after a mother substitute, Mrs. Victor, had died in his arms.  In that scene, Jim at first believed that the strange new light across the sky was Mrs. Victor's soul going to heaven. When Jim hears the report of the bomb on the radio, his identity is once again shattered. Jim now no longer worships the god of death and destruction, the airplane.  He believes that he now possesses the power of the sun, and is an almighty healer.  Believing his hands to possess supernatural powers after having witnessed the power of the sun, having seen the light from the explosion of the atomic bomb, Jim applies the same heart massage to the just-killed Japanese boy, while chanting, "I can bring them back.  Everyone."  As he moves forward and down massaging the chest of his shot friend, the light of the sun glares into the camera lens, then clears as Jim moves back up. This glare pattern, alternating with Jim, repeats many times.  We then see a shot of the body Jim is giving the heart massage to, and it has become the younger schoolboy Jim who has been left behind years earlier.  A few moments later, we see that it really is still the Japanese boy Jim is trying to revive, but blood oozes from his mouth with each press on his stopped heart. The young kamikaze pilot, with whom he shared model planes, and who protected him during his near-suicidal pheasant-hunt, in many ways represented Jim's confusing Japanese identity -- his double.  But he is very dead. Although heavy, this is great, meaning potentially classic, film-making.
With director Steven Spielberg at the helm you can't go wrong, with that being said, I think this is his best film and Christian Bale's best performance although his first.

It is pure genius. The best movie ever done, the best movie by Steven Spielberg, the best acting performance by Christian Bale, etc, etc.It let us see a War through a child's eyes, let us understand the meaning of freedom, wealth and poverty, it is truly touching.A classic all should see at least once in your life. You will not be the same.A final reference to the amazing music throughout the entire movie.The war, the Japanese, the British, a new world, a lost world, life & death, love and hate, friends with enemy.See it.

This film has been my favorite ever since I was first introduced to it when I was in the first or second grade. Although it is very close to being tied with The Shawshank Redemption.It has beautiful cinematography, one of my favorite scores, great acting (especially by Christian Bale), and...I don't know. It's just really good. But it's not for everyone. Some think it's too boring and slow. But I try to show it to everyone and recommend it to them, and some of them really enjoyed it.It's about Jamie, a British boy taken into a concentration camp, and his change, and so on.The greatest film of all time! I'm shocked that it's not even ON the Top 250, but oh well. And I've been waiting for the DVD for so long, and it finally came out a month or two ago!

Unfortunaly I missed about the first 1/2 hour of the film as I was searching through the channels on the T.V., but something about this movie caught my eye. Christian Bale is one of my favorite actors and it easy to see why. Even when he was a young you could tell that he was going to be a fabulous actor. This movie touched me so much, and pulled my right into their world. It was so real, so raw. The cast was amazing, and Speilburg hit the mark again. When the ending came I was on the edge of my seat, until the moment when his mother called out his name, and he was so relieved that he just couldn't believe it was her, it just ripped my heart out. This is now one of my favorite movies, so if you get the chance I highly recommend that you watch it.

reviews.review_title: One of Spielberg's Best (feel good movie)
reviews.content: The title of this movie, "Empire of the Sun" , gives an impression that it's some kind war movie. Well, it's not a war movies, instead it's a drama in time of the war, when Japan occupied China (Shanghai). But this movies captured my attention from the beginning until the end. The movie tell a story about the adventure of a boy from riches to rags, and from there he evolved from a spoil kid to a survivor. The scenery is amazing, from the city scenery to the dessert scenery, everything is a feast for the eye. The castings are superb, and the plot is stunning. Even with only Christian Bale (some of his solo performances in this movie are really good) and John Malkovich, the movie is very entertaining. The conversation between a child and a crook is always interesting. The plot develop naturally, and I can feel the evolution of the boy, with every experience that he confront. When I first saw the movie, I was still in the same age with "Jim", and until now every time the movie is in the program, I tune to the channel. Therefore, it's a feel good movie, and it's simply one of Spielberg's best.

I first saw this film back in 1987 when my parents took me to the theatre. I was five at the time, but the movie was something that held me tightly and would not let go. I guess it was Jim living on his own that fascinated me. I've never been on my own, but I always wondered what it was like, I was a child, my life revolved around kindergarten and episodes of Mister Rodgers Neighborhood. When "Empire" premiered on HBO a year later, I had my older brother record it for me. I watched it everyday and wore out the VCR. Ten years later I saw the film again, not as a little kid, but as a fifteen year old girl planning to be a movie director when I grew up. I catapulted into the story and relived many childhood memories as Jim "ran around trying to find his parents,"(that what I always thought it was about for ten years), I read the novel by J. G. Ballard and found all the symbolism Mr. Spielberg had put into it. It has always been my favourite film and has been since '87, as I watch the movie(at least once a week now) I see the five year old little girl that I once was. Steven Spielberg took us into to the life of a young British boy in a Japanese interment camp outside of Shanghai, China. Jim meets Frank and Basie after being "lost in the crowd" and becomes a pickpocket for Basie's constant errands. Four years later, as the war winds down, Jim questions a lot of things in his reality and can't remember what his parents look like. He doesn't want to leave the camp, but he wants to find his parents. This movie is my favourite film(I bet you're sick of hearing that!) and it should have won all six Oscars it was nominated for and more(including Best Picture). It's a cinematic achievement, one of Spielberg's best, and will live forever in movie history if people will watch it and admire it story and characters.

World war 2 movie always made us sad and felt lucky in a different way.The movie 'Empire of the Sun' really gave us some lesson about how horrible a war is.The survival of a lonely young English boy in China showed the world about bravery and high spirits is all about."You might cry after watching this movie, But there`s always something to cheer about"

reviews.review_title: Truly one of the finest of masterpieces...
reviews.content: I just rented this movie a few days ago.  I nearly cried at the end.  I've never seen such acting from a kid like I saw from Christian Bale.  His talent was very convincing.  The realism of the movie was awesome.  I really liked the scene where Jim is hugging the Zero and the POW camp officer is about to shoot him, when three Zero pilots walk up and see the boy in a state of awe at the plane.  The boy then turns to the pilots and salutes them--- and then the pilots stand at attention and salute back.  That is awesome!  I watched the movie twice and I know that I will have to buy it now.  It is truly one of my top five movies!  Great Job for Spielberg!

The film was really marvelous and quiet similar to the novel, christian bale performance was outstanding along with the great malkovich, the film has successful recited the era of war between us and Japan and has given us some great details about thylat. Though he didn't like it too much, this film remain one of Spielberg greatest achievement in the history of Cinema.The digital effect also were marvelous, though we are in 1987, it was really professional and well made, the thing to highlight here is the that this movies belongs to coming of age film, which has successfully described that transition between childhood and adulthood.

reviews.review_title: Impressive performance of a 13 years young boy !
reviews.content:
Christian Bale's amazing acting performance as a 13 years young boy is very impressive! I never understood why this performance wasn't honoured by at least an Oscar nomination!
For me one of the best performance of a child ever! A must-see movie just only because of this acting performance.

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies to date
reviews.content: The first time I saw the movie Empire Of The Sun,I have to admit parts of the film shocked me and even now as I have gotten older I still find myself turning away from the part where Jim's Japanese friend is shot and killed. But movies about disturbing events in history ought to shock us if they have been executed well by the direction and the actors in the film. Everyone worked well together to create a breathtaking and often amazing piece of film history...

Why did they have schoolboy Jim wear those ridiculous uniform 'shorts'? No contemporaneous English schoolboy would have been seen dead in that rig. They are at least four inches too long. An entertaining film but I really have to deduct three stars because of gross directional and wardrobe inauthenticity.

One of my all-time favorite movieI saw this film for the first time when I was about 10 years and I was terrified by it. As a child there was nothing more frightening to me than losing my parents and having to fend for yourself. But I was at the same time amazed by it and couldn't stop watching it. Now 7 years later, I have just seen it again and I just LOVE this movie! The acting is absolutely amazing, there's a lot of symbolism, the music is perfect, the emotions and the picture are FAN-TAS-TIC! ... Everything is absolutely breathtaking and heart-wrenching! The big questing: Why didn't it win an Oscars? I cannot believe that it didn't won for best picture and/or for best Director in 1987. The Last Emperor won both. If anyone can explain it to me, then please mail, I cannot see one good reason. I would like to add that I find the Empire of the Sun a true masterpiece in movie making. What is more wonderful than a movie that makes you think about life?10/10

At 15 , I failed to understand "Crash" and gave Ballard away. After all, he seemed to have given away his original science fiction. But my wife, despite her deafness, wants to watch a late TV screening of " ...... a wonderful book. Why haven't you read it?". Three hours later, I get to thank her for making me watch one of the great movies. Other comments list the exceptional qualities of the film, but most fail to give due credit to a fabulous script. Tom Stoppard has produced many masterworks and this is up with his best; at once understated AND memorable. So when you watch it, being swept along by the remarkable acting, the stunning visuals, the haunting themes, the moral ambiguities.... take in also the brilliance of a script that takes you through a "war" film without a single cliché. Thats all. This movie might serve to make me start again watching the things.... after 35 years of thinking that "film of artistic merit" is oxymoronic..... I was wrong about this one and probably about others.

This stunning masterpiece being overlooked proves the sad truth that most moviegoers have been willing to shut off their brains. This is not A-Z storytelling entertainment, but is pure art in movie making itself. I can think of at least 3 classes in which this movie can be shown for educational purpose. This movie contains rich symbolism and other literary devices, and the fact that it is based on a novel make it a must for an English/literature class. History classes can use it too since the film is about WWII. Drama classes must show it to serious students who want to learn a thing or two about acting from Christian Bale (which is beyond words). Film student definitely need to see this movie most of all.
The music score by John Williams is outstanding. The acting, especially from Christian Bale, is simply too astounding to explain. There are a lot of memorable scenes, but the ones that stands out most are: Kamikaze salute, atomic bomb, and of course the Cadillac of the sky.This is not a movie you should miss.

reviews.review_title: One of my top ten films of all time
reviews.content: I can't remember exactly how old I was when I first saw this movie, but I know I was quite young. It was at an age when my level of maturity was not to the degree that would allow me to appreciate serious dramas. I was still very much into the typical flashy and trashy fanfare most young kids my age liked. EOTS was the first serious movie I ever liked. It just absorbed me from beginning to end. It was utterly beautiful and moving, deeply emotional. It also had a great soundtrack that really complemented the movie. One of my strongest memories of this film is the solo choir bit in the soundtrack (I think it was sung by Christian Bale's character at some point). It was hauntingly beautiful. This is one of the few movies that I have held close to my heart over the years. Even my younger brother loved it and he is seven years younger than I (he was with me when I first saw this movie). It is a real shame that this movie did not get the attention/publicity it deserved (at least not where i'm from). Even up till today I haven't heard anyone mention this film. I'm not even sure it was shown in the local cinemas. Was it ever nominated for any awards? I was too young to remember. It would be  a grave injustice if it wasn't.

this is by far and away my most favorite film of all time....the seeds of SL and SPR are planted in this masterfully crafted tale of innocence lost during war....much more thought provoking than Platoon, which covers the same ground.... This is spielberg's first real masterpiece!!!!!

This is a great movie!  I loved it the first time I saw it during the original release.  I have seen it and never tired of it many times since. I am a middle school teacher, always looking for good G or PG movies to show my classes (they are hard to find!) I just showed this movie to my 6th, 7th and 8th graders.  At the end of the movie they cheered and applauded. Many said they wanted to rent it and show it to their parents and families. Comments included: "This is the best movie I ever saw"  "That movie was tight!"  "That was a cool movie, Miss!"  Girls and boys liked it equally. One of my sixth graders said he went home and had a discussion with his father about the atomic bomb. These kids weren't even born when this movie was made and only 2 out 200 had ever seen it.  This movie is a 10!!!

This movie touched me in a way that few movies ever have. Although "Empire" contains a great deal of artistry and imagery I feel that I can only fully express that at base this movie is about the innocence of children and the ties that are formed regardless of race or nationality before they are exposed to the hatred that adults force on them. Jim's journey is a long and complicated one but his innocent friendships with people like basie and the other camp victims show that he is unaware of his dangerous surroundings. This theme culminates with his befriending the young Japanese boy. The two form a bond even though there respective countries are at war with each other. Speilberg shows that only if we look at war as children can we ever hope to avoid it.

reviews.review_title: Fabulous acting by Christian Bale. Never been so impressed with child actor in my life.
reviews.content: I watched the film with my mouth hanging open with amazement as Bale (at age 12) tackled a difficult and moving role. IAs soon as the DVD was available I bought it. Couldn't get it here in UK at the time so bought the USA version which works perfectly in my DVD. I watch it regularly and it ALWAYS has the same emotional effect upon me. I am looking forward to seeing Bale in the new Batman movie as I think he is one of the best actors of our time. I have heard nothing but great reviews about Batman and having seen Christian in other movies I can be sure of a great evening. Of course, as soon as the Batman movie comes out on DVD I shall be first in the queue to buy it. I am SO looking forward to seeing one of my fave actors (who I have watched more or less 'grow up' on screen) in a Movie that everyone says is BRILLIANT. Go for it Christian, you have been superb so far. Keep it up.

reviews.review_title: briliant narrative of war through child's eyes, flawless
reviews.content: I've heard and actually read once that this is one of the most underrated films in history.  I almost wish it would have been released after Schindler's List and Pvt. Ryan because only now does it seem Speilberg is being given the credit he deserves.  I remember seeing this film as a child and relating to it so well, I almost felt as though I was in the film (pardon the melodrama and cliche).  I've rarely seen a film that could portray so honestly the perspective of a child in such harsh times as this film, and Christian Bale's performance is one of the best ever by a child. This film starts off so beautifully, I once read that the first half was the best Speilberg has ever done.  The writer said, however, that the film seems to fall apart at the end.  I think that it is beautiful how the film starts to be erratic at the end which wonderfully emulates what Jim is experiencing.  The only film I watched years ago and today still cry at.The scene where the P-51 pilot waves to Jim right before he realizes he has forgotten what his parents look like is possibly the greatest scene I have ever seen in a film.  The ending is as touching as cinema can get.

Empire of the Sun is one of those movies that, if you are not paying attention, can be bitter or harsh after sampling.  I compare the movie to a fine wine--it gets better with age.When I first saw Empire of the Sun after it was released, I had mixed emotions leaving the theater.  To me, the story seemed to flow flawlessly until the release of the prisoners from the prison camp.  Then the story seemed to get muddled and confused, not knowing at the time that this is what Steven Spielberg was wanting to accomplish.  For many years, I had a love-hate relationship with the movie; there were so many things I liked, but so many things I would have liked to have seen differently.But Empire of the Sun is one of those movies that does get better with age. When I first saw the movie, I still pictured Spielberg's movies in a common theme--action-adventure (Jaws, Close Encounters, E.T., and the Indiana Jones movies).  I kept this love-hate relationship with this movie until Spielberg started producing his more serious work (Schindler's List, Amistad and Saving Private Ryan).  I now realize the genius that was Empire of the Sun, and I bet if the movie critics had a second look at this movie now, they would realize that this movie belongs on the short list of Spielberg's best movies.  I am now proud to call it one of my favorite movies.It is one of the most beautifully-filmed movies I have ever seen.  Perhaps the reason this is Spielberg's most misunderstood movies is that the master storyteller lets the film and the music tell the story, and not necessarily by use of dialogue.  While John Williams will be remembered for the musical scores of other Spielberg films (Jaws, Close Encounters, Raiders of the Lost Ark, even Schindler's List), this is truly John William's masterpiece that, in my opinion, even he has yet to top.  Its as if Spielberg commissioned the music first, then filmed around the music.  What is not said in the film is just as important as what is said.Christian Bale gives the performance of a lifetime as Jim, the young boy who is separated from his parents after the Japanese take Shanghai during World War II, and the stories of his struggle for survival in a prison camp until the end of the war.  To this day, I am still shocked that a 13-year-old could give such a commanding performance, acting toe-to-toe with the likes of John Malkovich, Nigel Havers and Miranda Richardson.The story intentionally gets muddled about two-thirds of the way through the movie.  But as the allied forces slowly inch their way to China, things are naturally going to get confusing, when the only goal of the characters is survival.  This is one of those movies that you learn from each time you see it, until finally you learn enough to understand that this is exactly what Spielberg had in mind when he made this movie.If you have not seen the film, or if you haven't seen it in a long time, I encourage you to rent the movie and enjoy it all over again.  I could go on talking forever, but in summary, I believe that this years from now that Empire of the Sun will go down as one of Spielberg's best films. Enjoy.

reviews.review_title: One of the best movie I've ever seen
reviews.content: Awesome in all aspect! This movie is a piece of art! ... showing through Jim's eyes the war!

reviews.review_title: Beautiful illustration of the conflict between loyalty and survival
reviews.content: A magnificent movie this is, indeed.  But I don't agree at all that it is about war -- the war serves only as a backdrop to the interaction between Jim, his hero Basie, and his surrogate parents Mr. and Mrs. Victor. Precocious yet innocent Jim picks up quickly on lessons from "the university of life" and is seduced by the exciting but survivalist ways of the American GI.  Ultimately the glamourous illusion is shattered by betrayal, and Jim learns the meaning of true loyalty and care when Mr. and Mrs. Victor take him back as their own child.  Jim grows out of his naivety when he sees through Basie's final attempt to seduce him (by offering to take him to his parents), yet he retains his charming innocence with a polite "Yes please, Basie" when offered a Hershey Bar (for real).  In the end, what is this movie really about?  The tragedy of a lost childhood.

reviews.review_title: Christian Bale shines as a young boy retaining his childhood in a very grown- up world.
reviews.content: As  a Christian Bale fan, I went into this movie fully expecting to see the grown up sort-of Bale that I have enjoyed in his more recent films. I instead saw him as an equally amazing child actor, richly deserving of the recognition he got for his performance. A Steven Spielberg film is an amazing stage for a rising actor, and Bale showed that he had talent worthy of such a prestigious movie. And since, Bale has not faded as many child actors, but built a career based on many complex and diverse characters. If you go see the upcoming "American Psycho" expect to see a very different Bale as Patrick Bateman. After all, isn't good acting being able to be effective in any role?

Naive, slow, maudlin, superficial.  These are the criticisms typically leveled at this film.  Coming after "The Color Purple", it was regarded as another overly sentimental attempt by the director to take on "serious" subject matter.  Critics may be easily enough dismissed, but I read somewhere that no less a figure than the great Japanese director Akira Kurosawa sent Spielberg a letter taking him to task for "Empire of the Sun". Perhaps he took offense at the way the Japanese were portrayed in the film. I'd be very curious to know exactly what his criticism were, but I imagine the thrust of it was that Spielberg's Disney-ish world-view was inappropriate in the context of a serious and important subject such as WWII.Spielberg seemed to have taken these criticisms to heart, because when he came back to WWII again, he approached it in a radically different way. "Schindler's List" and "Saving Private Ryan" give us a window into the era that is painfully transparent.  Our collective knowledge of this time comes from newsreel footage and the recollections of those that lived through it. Spielberg drew on these elements and created two films of striking verisimilitude.Now that Spielberg has his Oscar and no one accuses of him of being incapable with "serious stuff", I think is now possible to fully appreciate "Empire of the Sun".This is not just a stepping-stone to his later, "truly mature" films, but a great work in its own right - one that in my mind forms an integral and compelling WWII trilogy with "Schindler" and "Ryan".Whereas the later films take a profound and unblinking look at the horrors of the death camps and the battlefields, I think in many ways "Empire" actually goes a little deeper.  WWII was not just an epic, global human experience, but a transforming moment in history.  1945 wasn't just the year WWII ended - it was the end of an era.  It clearly marked all that followed as a new and modern age (both exciting and dangerous).There is nostalgia about WWII.  I think this nostalgia runs deep for a very simple reason.  With WWII, the events of Auschwitz and Hiroshima, the world became a place whose end was no longer just hypothetical, but very possible. "Empire of the Sun" is a film that expresses this wider sociological impact of the war quite tellingly.For Americans, however, nostalgia for WWII isn't just a yearning for a simpler, less dangerous time.  Maybe this is why Spielberg's intent with "Empire" was largely lost on his American audiences.  WWII brought the nation together in powerful ways and catapulted it onto the center of the world stage.  America was victorious, after all.  If Americans have a perception of those times as Big-Band fun and GI Joe heroics, Hollywood has certainly played a big part in forming it.  If any filmmaker is especially attuned to this fact, it is Spielberg.  His earlier "1941" was a reasonably (though not entirely) successful attempt to pay tribute and parody the Hollywood wartime propaganda that we've all grown up with."Empire", through its unique story, allows WWII to be viewed from different and vital perspectives.  The protagonist, Jim (brilliantly played by Christian Bale) is not the typical Spielberg "gee-whiz" kid, in spite of any superficial similarities; but a precocious, sheltered, rebelliously minded son of an English ex-patriot living in the Far East.  He likes to read GI Joe comics, but he also is an atheist, and writes books on contract bridge.The Americans in "Empire of the Sun" (splendidly personified by John Malkovich through his character Basie) aren't stereotypes either.  Behind the "Joe Cool" sunglasses and "Hi'ya, pal" facades are calculating opportunists.  Even the antagonists, the Japanese, are not depicted simply as "Bonzai" fanatics; we are allowed to see them as committed and courageous warriors too."Empire of the Sun" is a great story about the loss of innocence, not just that of a spoilt English choir boy, but of the collective innocence of the world.  It may lack the subtlety of "Summer of '42" or the wistful charm of "Hope and Glory", but "Empire of Sun" shows us a WWII that isn't just grim horror and tragedy, isn't John Wayne guts and glory either - but an ironic mixture of both, which characterizes the subject pretty accurately I think.If any moment in the film best shows the strength of Spielberg's effort here, it must be the moment where the terrified Jim is lost, racing through the war-torn streets of Shanghai.  He's separated from his parents, pursued by a dangerous ruffian - and comes upon a gigantic mural of "Gone with the Wind".  It is one of those blatant but compelling cinematic images, like Orson Welles pontificating before an enormous backdrop of Charles Foster Kane.This is one of many great moments in a stirring and thought-provoking film, moments I won't soon forget:Jim chasing his glider up a hill only to come upon a company of Japanese troops preparing to invade his world...Jim signaling a Japanese destroyer with his flashlight and getting an explosive response...Jim snatching a food dish from the grip of a dead prisoner...A lost boy in a lost world finding his heroes where he can (saluting Japanese airmen)...His surrogate mother dies in his arms as the world enters the nuclear age... (Subtle symbolism may be more aesthetically pleasing, but it is not always so effective)The euphoria of liberation, the hysteria of civilians caught in the deadly crossfire of war... (The Mustang air attack sequence - a splendid example of Spielberg's filmmaking craft as any!)Jim, a listless refugee, casting away his suitcase, letting go of all that used to define him and give him certainty...Jim frantically trying to resuscitate his Japanese alter-ego...Spielberg has always been very conscious of the cinematic legacy he has inherited.  Kurosawa may have hated it, but I can't imagine that David Lean wouldn't have admired this film as much as I do.

This is a less known work of Spielberg, but it is one of his best. The plot is wonderful, and shows a rarely seen side of World War II. The sound track is John Williams best work in my opinion. The movie reveals the innocence of childhood contrasted against the insane and inhuman background of a prison camp. Definitely a must see for any movie buff.

reviews.review_title: Worth seeing more than once, especially if you own the DVD.
reviews.content: Young Jim Graham from the film Empire of the Sun could easily earn some consideration for the top 100 movie characters of all time. Jim really propels this film forward and we are provided the opportunity to see this spoiled British child, separated from his parents in Hong Kong, grow into a crafty adolescent survivor struggling with life and death in a Japanese internment/prison camp during WWII.Defining Moment worth seeing over and over again: Finds Jim up on the roof of a tall building staring transfixed into the sky as Mustang fighter pilots begin strafing and dive bombing the air strip dangerously close to his camp. You can almost taste the awe and majesty that Jim is experiencing when we see and hear him screaming out to speedy, attacking aircraft, "WOW, GO, P-51... Cadillac of the skies, P-51... Cadillac of the skies ...Horsepower...!!!" no soon after one fighter pilot smilingly waves back to him (with canopy open) in a surreal, slow motion "on the deck" fly by.

I saw this movie as a child. And almost 20 years later, it's still my favorite. I was drawn to watch the movie because of the beautiful music and the stunning cinematography. But the movie goes even beyond that. It is a story about a young British boy who survives a brutal Japanese concentration camp through his innocence, energy and enthusiasm. For me, it wasn't a story about a war. It was about how an adversity will not destroy a strong human spirit. While everyone else is succumbing to the brutalities of WWII, the young boy never loses his purity and enthusiasm for life and people. He is trusting, loyal, optimistic and brave. And his Japanese counterpart (the young kamikaze) shows this as well. Two young boys become friends, even though they should be enemies because they do not know hate, greed and cynicism that people develop as they get older. The best thing about the movie was Christian Bale's acting - amazing what expressiveness such a young actor can have (he is also amazing in American Psycho and The Machinist). This movie is Spielberg's cinematic masterpiece.

I think this movie was so under-rated! Christian Bale should have gotten an academy award for this portrayal of a child and his ability to survive in the harshest of circumstances. I don't think Christian Bale has gotten the recognition he deserves as an artist and I predict in the near future, he will! Every time this movie is on, I watch it. The most moving part of the movie, to me, is the song he sings while saluting the Japanese air force - wow. It gives me chill bumps! And of course, why didn't I realize it was a Steve Spielburg movie! The sky was beautiful! You must see this movie if you have not! The change his character does in the movie, from the beginning to the end, is remarkable. He should have gotten an Academy Award!

I first saw Empire of the Sun as a teenager and loved it then. I recently watched it again and had much more appreciation for it. I have many favourite scenes, including the scene when Jim salutes the Japanese pilots.FAV 1 -The scene that puts a big lump in my throat is when Jim starts to sing "Suo Gan". I love this song and actually discovered that it is a Welsh Lullaby.FAV 2 -My other favourite scene is when Jim tells the very sick Mrs. Victor to pretend she is dead. Which they both do to avoid having to continue on with the other prisoners. Jim wakes up and tries to wake Mrs. Victor, but she is dead. Then a brilliant light fills the sky and Jim thinks it was Mrs. Victor's soul going to heaven when in actual fact what he saw was the bombing of Hiroshima.FAV 3 -Now that I am a mother, I found the last scene very emotional. All the mothers and fathers looking at a crowd of children desperately hoping to see their childs face. Jim's parents move through the crowd, until Jims mother sees Jim and holds him tight.A beautiful story of War through the eyes of a child, who through his experiences matures years beyond his age.Other Favourite movies; The Last of the Mohicans, Rudy, Schindlers List, Glory.

Many years passed and I watch it again and I couldn't stop the tears from running though my eyes. That's why I think the Empire of the Sun is one of Spielberg's best movie ever made. I can't get enough of watching it. It's such a beautiful film and one of my personal favorites.

reviews.review_title: A boy's search for his lost family amidst the conflict of WWII.
reviews.content: I feel that this is one of Steven Spielberg's best works while it seems to fly under the radar. The story of a young boy who finds himself amidst the turmoil of a world under the wages of war and in the end finds the beauty within the evil. I think that the cinematography, score and the actors under Spielberg were awesome, but perhaps most important of all- it's a tremendous story. As a film student it's the kind of film that I love because it's the reason I go to the theater and make pictures. In the end you walk away and hopefully your a better person than when you arrived. Now that's the power of a great film, and Spielberg has the vision to make it happen.

reviews.review_title: No more than what it is
reviews.content:
I reviewed the reviews. We all slam on critics for their obsessive broad stroking of films.  Yet I see much of that here.  The movie is more of a human charactor study than anything else.  Many slam the movie for not making a big issue of their particular perspective of wartime China.  But look closer at what is happening in the film.You start with a kid that is spoiled.  Yes he gets slapped by his house person.  Given the implied behavior of the kid, I'd slap him too.  But let the story progress from there.Take a spoiled kid and toss him into a new reality.  One that is unprotected.  He must now deal with every day using the behaviors as he only knows how.  So to some, many of his reactions may seem abstract or hard to follow.  Lets face it, kids do not see the world as adults do.  And reality is pretty tough to understand for them at times. But as time goes on, the kid is broken down more in to a child seeking survival.
To look at this movie expecting political comment is unfair.  A child does not see the world in a political way.  As the film travels on, we see how a child must try and figue out just what is real,what is going on, where is safety, where is the security(of family) and adapt. This movie shows how easy it is for a young mind to get lost in all of the changes of the world around him.  I do not see any indication in the film that "Jim" aligns himself with anyone or cause.  What he see's in the Japanese boy in the camp is simply another boy.  (The contrast and clash of their pasts and destinies are interesting).The exposure "Jim" is given to the confused World during wartime is real. In the end, we do not see him as the matured man of the world.  We see a worn out spent individual that is simply human and survided.If you go into this movie without trying to politisize or over complicate it, you will find it quite enjoyable.  Go looking for a political statement or docu-drama, and you will not like it.
